newsitem.title: USA: Koch restructuring Texas, Minnesota refineries.
newsitem.headline: Koch restructuring Texas, Minnesota refineries.

text.p: Koch Refining Co plans to invest $200 million in processing and information management equipment to upgrade refineries in Corpus Christi, Texas and Rosemount, Minn., the company said on Tuesday.

Koch, a unit of Wichita, Ka.-based Koch Industries Inc, also plans to cut its workforce at the refineries by about 25 percent as part of a restructuring to be completed by July 1999, the company said.

"This restructuring is essential if Koch Refining is to compete with newer, world-class operations, and with facilities overseas that do not face the regulatory requirements and associated costs we have domestically," Koch Refining President Jim Imbler said in a statement.

The 1,100-person workforce at the Corpus refinery was expected to be cut to 800, and the 750-person workforce at the Pine Bend refinery in Rosemount would fall to about 600, a spokesman said. A voluntary severance program for refinery workers and managers was expected to account for a "significant portion" of the reductions.

Spokesman Jay Rosser declined to comment on projected savings from the restructuring, which was geared to keeping the two Koch plants off a list of 145 refineries shut down or scaled back in the past two decades.
"It's our commitment to remain in the refining industry," he said. "We are committed not to become another number on that list."
Rosser said the refineries have a combined capacity of about 600,000 barrels per day, which would not be significantly affected by the new equipment.
